physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long, typed on plain paper. The words “Little Review” are written in pencil at the top.

div.p: I am awfully sorry about your being so low in funds; but I suppose now it is just like pouring money into a bottomless pit. I send you a ten-dollar bill, to make up for the subscribers I have not the time to hunt for; and you know I will do everything for you that I possibly can.

Keep yourself above water, for Heaven sake! I think all of us would feel it as a great loss, if the magazine were to stop. I have an idea! Why don’t you ask every poet or prose writer who has ever written for you, or with whom you are in any way connected, to send you a copy of their books, autographed with an interesting inscription, and then auction them off somewhere at some fair? They are trying this, collecting autograph copies, at Brown’s Bookshop here, and they expect to sell the books afterwards as a collection; but that would be too slow a business for you. You would make some money anyway, and I do not believe there is a writer who would not be glad to help you in this way. If
you like my suggestion, let me know, and I will send you my book, done up for sale. Good luck to you anyway, and do not lose courage! Sincerely yours,
